topics.body:
So next month comes a patch that promises to make Diablo III a million times better. I bought it and it was a really depressing experience for me, if only because I could see a good game trying to get out but hampered by a lot of stupid bullshit (most notably, the fucking real money auction house and the resulting crappy loot system and always online requirement. If I'm playing a game single player I should not be dying because of lag.)

Supposedly this patch is going to make Diablo III the game it was supposed to be. I'm going to give it another chance (I mean, I already blew the sixty bucks on it so why not?) and I'm curios if anyone else is.
topics.author: 4f41ee04945b701c41002af7

topics.body:
I was reading the news and came across this:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/20/garden/small-world-big-idea.html?_r=0

You know, as someone that has been homeless before this is a really good idea; the reason being is that homeless shelters a lot of the money gets eaten up by construction, having 24/7 staff all the time and so forth.  By the time a person gets a room most of the money donations have been eaten up due to just construction and maintnance.  Also homeless shelters feel like prisons.  Having communities where for the same cost you can have ten times the amount of people, unless it's one of those shelters where everyone is illegally packed like sardines, would be a good thing.

topics.body:
I know nobody cares, and I don't know why I'm so steamed about it, but after reading "this manga,":http://myanimelist.net/manga/5341/Honjitsu_mo_Muteki5 I feel perturbed.

It sucks to be a fan of old shoujo manga and constantly find romances that basically end with the female protagonist changing herself for a guy (usually in some aspect that, at the beginning of the story, made her feel comfortable, whether it be dressing like a guy, saving copious amounts of money, etc.)...and being _rewarded_ for it (getting the guy). Dunno, it just rubs me the wrong way. In this story, despite loving dressing like a guy, the protagonist changes her outfit to the more girly side because "my best friend since I was a child says that I'm not a boy and he likes me like this", I guess. 

What really confuses me is that shoujo romance usually tries to display the "perfect" romance for its female audience, so to see it advocated that you should change some harmless part of yourself for a guy just sucks. I get that Japan has different morals or whatever, but...ugh.

What cracks me up is that the manga is called "Even Today I Am Strong". Like, what? How are you strong? I guess there was a bit where she confronted her daddy issues, kind of, but the entire story was centered around her dressing like a girl for the people around her, not herself (friends, her mother, her best friend), despite liking how she already dressed.


"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5306d1aa63687246c3ec0100#post_5306d1aa63687246c3ec0100

Heh.
topics.author: 5041b54f7f123b77af00a442

Isn't that what most teenagers do? They try to be something they are not just to get the attention of someone they will likely forget by the time graduation kicks in.
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5306d7c863687254f3c40000#post_5306d7c863687254f3c40000

Yeah, but you know frilly shoujo romances. Had the manga continued past one volume, I'd bet my house that the two would have stayed together past college, probably would have gotten married.

Couples in shoujo might fight, but if the author's already confirmed that they're "perfect" for one another? No way in hell they'll break up, and if they do, it's only temporary.
topics.author: 5041b54f7f123b77af00a442

topics.body:
"@And Brother I Hurt People":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5306d85863687255f5350100#post_5306d85863687255f5350100

Then you would probably like to read some Josei manga if you want a more realistic approach in relationships.

Of course, they tend to be bittersweet at best. (I've only read some bits of Paradise Kiss and XXHolic, yet Hetalia isn't considered one... huh.)

And I agree, Shojo tends to play it safe most of the time, but I laso liek the fact that most endings are ambiguous since for japanese, the ending is not important as much as how they develop and make their relationship grow. I think it has to do with how wrokaholics they are and marriage ends up being a compromise were you can't do anything else except working.
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4
